articles.headline: Union Says G.M. Strike Won’t End Until Workers Vote on Deal
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers said the tentative contract agreement would provide wage increases and improve the prospects of temporary employees.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers said the tentative contract agreement would provide wage increases and improve the prospects of temporary employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The longest strike against General Motors in half a century isn’t over yet.

articles.headline: Trump Will Host Next G7 Summit at His Doral Resort
articles.snippet: “It’s almost like they built this facility to host this type of event,” the acting White House chief of staff said, dismissing questions over the propriety of the president’s picking his own hotel.
articles.abstract: “It’s almost like they built this facility to host this type of event,” the acting White House chief of staff said, dismissing questions over the propriety of the president’s picking his own hotel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has decided to host the Group of 7 meeting next June at the Trump National Doral near Miami, Mick Mulvaney, the president’s acting chief of staff, said Thursday, a decision that prompted immediate questions about whether it was a conflict of interest for him to choose one of his own properties for a diplomatic event.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Defiant Zuckerberg Says Facebook Won’t Police Political Speech
articles.snippet: In an address at Georgetown University, the Facebook chief executive called for more free speech — not less — as his company has been assailed for allowing lies and falsehoods to appear.
articles.abstract: In an address at Georgetown University, the Facebook chief executive called for more free speech — not less — as his company has been assailed for allowing lies and falsehoods to appear.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren recently accused Facebook of being a “disinformation-for-profit machine.” Marc Benioff, chief executive of the online software maker Salesforce, said the social network “needs to be held accountable for propaganda on its platform.” And regulators around the world are examining whether to break the company up or clip its power.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Mulvaney Says, Then Denies, That Trump Held Back Ukraine Aid as Quid Pro Quo
articles.snippet: Conflicting comments by the acting White House chief of staff threw  Washington into turmoil.
articles.abstract: Conflicting comments by the acting White House chief of staff threw  Washington into turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, threw the Trump administration’s defense against impeachment into disarray on Thursday when he said that the White House withheld nearly $400 million in military aid to Ukraine to further President Trump’s political interests.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: ‘It’s the Only Way to Get Paid’: A Struggle for Citgo, Venezuela’s U.S. Oil Company
articles.snippet: Citgo could become a casualty of the turmoil in Venezuela if the country’s national oil company fails to make a bond payment due at the end of the month.
articles.abstract: Citgo could become a casualty of the turmoil in Venezuela if the country’s national oil company fails to make a bond payment due at the end of the month.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Citgo has long been a mainstay of the American oil industry, with three major refineries, 4,500 gasoline stations and an iconic sign looming over Fenway Park’s left field wall.

articles.headline: Why Is a Secretive Billionaire Buying Up the Cayman Islands?
articles.snippet: The heir to a foam-cup fortune is believed to own more land than anyone on the storied tax haven of Grand Cayman, just as rising seas threaten to engulf it.
articles.abstract: The heir to a foam-cup fortune is believed to own more land than anyone on the storied tax haven of Grand Cayman, just as rising seas threaten to engulf it.
articles.lead_paragraph: One humid Tuesday in July, I summited the highest point on Grand Cayman, an eight-story dump known affectionately by the locals as Mount Trashmore. From the top of the foul mound — a collection of almost every piece of garbage discarded on the island since it went all-in on financial services in the 1960s — I imagined I could just make out the enshrouded beach estate of the secretive investor Kenneth Dart.

articles.headline: China’s Cryptocurrency Plan Has a Powerful Partner: Big Brother
articles.snippet: Facebook’s Libra project led Beijing to accelerate its efforts. The government could soon know a lot more about how people are spending.
articles.abstract: Facebook’s Libra project led Beijing to accelerate its efforts. The government could soon know a lot more about how people are spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Facebook announced plans this year for a cryptocurrency called Libra, it said its goal was to reinvent money for the internet age. What the company probably didn’t imagine was that its efforts might spur China to get there first.

articles.headline: Johnson & Johnson Recalls Baby Powder Over Asbestos Worry
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. found trace levels of asbestos in samples from a bottle of baby powder bought from an online retailer.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. found trace levels of asbestos in samples from a bottle of baby powder bought from an online retailer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson, which has spent years insisting that its baby powder is safe, recalled 33,000 bottles of the product on Friday after the Food and Drug Administration discovered evidence of asbestos, a known carcinogen, in one of the bottles.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Roni Caryn Rabin

articles.headline: ‘This Is Not Hard’: PG&E Gets an Earful Over Its Blackout
articles.snippet: The head of California’s biggest utility, under fire over the company’s handling of a pre-emptive power shut-off, faced scrutiny from state regulators.
articles.abstract: The head of California’s biggest utility, under fire over the company’s handling of a pre-emptive power shut-off, faced scrutiny from state regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Executives of California’s largest power company received withering criticism from state regulators Friday over a pre-emptive blackout that left millions without power, some for days.

articles.headline: On Day 1,001, Trump Made It Clear: Being ‘Presidential’ Is Boring
articles.snippet: If he acted “presidential,” Mr. Trump said Thursday night in Dallas, “everybody would be out of here so fast.”
articles.abstract: If he acted “presidential,” Mr. Trump said Thursday night in Dallas, “everybody would be out of here so fast.”
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — At one point during one of his most unpresidential of days, President Trump insisted that he knew how to be presidential.
